introduction: About James
James was the younger brother of Jesus.
Wealth of knowledge, may sound like his older brother sometimes.
Cross reference into the Gospels and Jesus Teachings
Book of James thought to be written 40 AD.
James is mentioned in Jerusalem Council: Act 15.
James was martyred 62 AD.
summary: Blueprint for how to think, act, plan as a Christian.
Book can be crushingly hard. Reading it can make me feel like a failure.
Important to dwell on the gospel: Now that I have been redeemed, how do I live?
Now that I have heard the word of God, how do I do it?
Spirits power: Remind ourselves the reason why we can attempt to be this way.
James isn't telling us how to get saved, he is telling us how to live now that we are saved.
Try and mix in some encouragement from other his and other books.

introduction: 1. As a Christian, how do I approach various trials? (e.g. Ecc and toil.)
2. Should I try to avoid trials?
3. What role do they play in my spiritual growth?
summary: 1. Approach trials with joy.
2. We should pray not to have trials, but when they do come, see them as a tool for our eternal good.
3. Some trials are self-induced.
3. Not about making lemonaid from lemons.
3. I need to consider carefully the difficulties in life and the possibility of them being part of my refinement.
3. But the plan of God for our refinement with eternal purpose.
3. Find true joy knowing that God has taken a loving interest in me. That He is treating me as a son.

introduction: Transition: Seems appropriate to talk about wisdom in light of the preceeding verses about trials.

1. Who is eligible for this wisdom? (age, educational background, intellectual abilities, demonination)
2. What type of wisdom is James talking about?
3. What are the conditions?
4. Why is God so displeased when we doubt Him?
summary: 1. All Christians are eligible and in need of God's wisdom.
2. a). It is distinct from intellectualism, b). Free from our own abilities (e.g. pride) c). Free gift for anyone who asks.
3. Only condition/requirement is to believe and not doubt that he will deliever on his promise to give wisdom.
3. Careful not to be double-minded.
3. Not pray once, get wisdom, and then move on to the next area, it is a continous process.
3. Amazing kindness of God for His provisions.
4. It dishonors him.
Wisdom from above: (parallels salvation)
=> independent of intellectualism or intellectual effort.
=> independent of our abilities (gives to all)
=> independent of our sinfulness. (without reproach)
=> dependent upon continuous faith (don't expect anything otherwise.)

Transition: How much to give? Where to give?

Money is a trial for me, I should find joy in that trial, I need wisdom to manage it, need steadfastness to keep from doubting.

introduction: How did you do last week with your words? Quick to listen? Did you get angry with anyone?

Powerful theme of James: Our faith is coupled to action
Faith and works are inseparable.
summary: John 15:1-12 I am the true vine, and my Father is the vinedresser. Every branch in me that does not bear fruit he takes away, and every branch that does bear fruit he prunes, that it may bear more fruit. Already you are clean because of the word that I have spoken to you. Abide in me, and I in you. As the branch cannot bear fruit by itself, unless it abides in the vine, neither can you, unless you abide in me. I am the vine; you are the branches. Whoever abides in me and I in him, he it is that bears much fruit, for apart from me you can do nothing.
Just like faith and works, hearing and doing are inseparable.
Am I doing enough to be a doer?
Jesus tells almost anticipates the question, but assures us that we are clean because of him.
Jesus says you can't be a doer without me. You need me to bear fruit.
Instead of asking the death spiral question, admit that I don't have it in me and ask the Lord of of Glory to help me do.

introduction: James uses the poor and the rich to make his points in chapter 2, the first being about discrimination, second faith and works.

You shall do no injustice in court. You shall not be partial to the poor or defer to the great, but in righteousness shall you judge your neighbor. You shall not go around as a slanderer among your people, and you shall not stand up against the life of your neighbor: I am the LORD. You shall not hate your brother in your heart, but you shall reason frankly with your neighbor, lest you incur sin because of him. You shall not take vengeance or bear a grudge against the sons of your own people, but you shall love your neighbor as yourself: I am the LORD.
Leviticus is speaking directly about the courts, James might also be about the courts inparticular, but is certainly not limited to that.
summary: James tells us not only to be very careful about how we treat people, but be especially careful when treating them differently based upon how we perceive them.
What is your image of a poor man: mine is someone on the corner with a sign, or those who hang out at the park by my house.
They are poor because of the choices they are making. There are jobs everywhere.
They must have decided not to work.
They probably decided to use drugs or alcohol.
They were not disciplined by their parents.
They grew up without a father in the house.
They have chosen, or their parents have chosen to disobey God's Word.
This is why I choose not to follow the news.
I don't know this, I donâ€™t know these people

Law of liberty => By believing in Jesus, we have the double cure: penalty of sin, free from it's power.
Law of liberty => I will give you a new heart, and the holy spirit, because that is what is required to act this way
Law of liberty => James 1:21 (receive with meekness the implanted word, which is able to save your souls.)
Law of liberty => Because God did this for me and to me, I can't take credit for it (or boast about it) and God will be glorified.
Law of liberty => Doesn't mean I don't strive to be the man God desires. I still need to work at the doing.
Law of liberty => Strive: Luke 13:24(narrow gate), 1 Tim 4:10, Heb 4:11, Effort: 2 Pet 1:5

summary: James, again, puts us in this impossible situation.
He uncovers our sin, presents it on a platter to us, and tells us we can't stop ourselves.
My tongue is a restless evil, a world of unrighteousness, it's full of deadly poison, it defiles you.
My tongue is a fire, it sets the course of your life on fire with a fire from hell.
I can't do anything about it because, I can't tame my own tongue, no one can.
What are we to do?
Cut it out, like Jesus talks about cutting off our hand or foot or eye.
That might help this problem, but there are plenty of others.
This is the same position he puts us in with the other topics he has presented.
=> Finding Joy in trials, if I remain steadfast: I will be perfect and complete, receiving the crown of life.
=> I ask for wisdom in perfect faith without any doubting.
=> Not giving into temptation.
=> Being a good listener, without becoming angry, and to put away the rampant wickedness.
=> Being a doer who acts and not a hearer only.
=> Not judging or showing partiality.
=> Having faith and works.
What are we to do?
How do we satisfy God's standard when James shows us so clearly that we can't?
The only thing we can do: repent and believe
When God shows us our sin, we repent (acknowledge and turn from it), and believe it the righteouness that Christ gives us.
To use James's words
... accept with meekness the implanted word that is able to save your souls.
... every good gift and perfect gift is from above.
We are not going to make ourselves perfect, but Jesus did, he is a perfect gift from above.
Throughout our sorjourne we are to recall that His perfect and sinless life, and the perfect sacrifice, make me righteous before God.
... Of his own will he brought us forth by the word of truth so that we should be a kind of firstfruits of his creatures.
Don't be discouraged or overwhelmed by James. Be encouraged because it was his own will, God so loved the world.
